value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">3</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was the printed book with the authors name attached that</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was the death of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs>. <add hand="ms" place="above">After that</add>The audience was separated from</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the singer. After that (1478) the sing was attached to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the singer. Anon gives place to James or Thomas; he lives in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in a house; and he has books.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">....2....</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The heart of this vast proliferation of printed</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">pages is the song. The song has the same power over the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reader in the 20th century as over the hearer in the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">11th. To enjoy singing, to enjoy 
            <choice>
              <sic>h aring</sic>
              <corr>hearing</corr>
            </choice> the song,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">must be the deepest rooted and tough of human instincts.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It is an instinct of self-preservation, for only when we</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">put two and two together to we overcome dissolution. Two</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">lines, two words, two 
            <choice>
              <sic>bri cks</sic>
              <corr>bricks</corr>
            </choice> make way against oblivion.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">Making whatever it is gives us life;</del> and the passion</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with which we seek for these creations, and attempt to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">make them, is of a piece with the instinct that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sets us preserving our bodies from wet, or cold.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But with the printing press came into existence</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">forces that cover over the original song--books</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">themselves and the readers of books. Could we at this</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">this moment X ray the singers mind we shound <add hand="ms" place="inline">f</add>ind</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a nimbus surrounding the song; a 
            <choice>
              <sic>st eam</sic>
              <corr>stream</corr>
            </choice> of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">influences <del hand="ms">to which so many ugly 
            <choice>
              <sic>abstarct</sic>
              <corr>abstract</corr>
            </choice></del> names have been</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">given-- <del hand="ms">influences</del> of <del hand="ms">society</del>; of education; of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">class; <add hand="ms" place="above">material; economic</add> of 
            <choice>
              <sic>econmic</sic>
              <corr>economic</corr>
            </choice> stress. So many are they and so</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">obscure that we may call them nonsense names--</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">say <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-nin" key="Nin">Nin</rs>, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-crot" key="Crot">Crot</rs> and <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-pull" key="Pulley">Pully</rs>. Nin Crot and Pully are always</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">at their task. 
            <choice>
              <sic>?ore</sic>
              <corr>More</corr>
            </choice> and more [complex]</l>
